docs.lead_paragraph: This week marks the beginning of Lent, when many of us choose to abstain from meat or dairy products — making this the perfect time to try new vegan dishes. Today: baked beans with mint, peppers and tomatoes.

headline.main: Napping on Game Day Is Prevalent Among N.B.A. Players
headline.sub: For a great majority of N.B.A. players, setting aside 20 minutes, or three hours, for sleeping is a key part of the pregame ritual.;

docs.abstract: Daytime naps are frequent ritual for many NBA players, whose schedules often are marked by late games and early practices.

docs.lead_paragraph: Hotels have been on a health kick in the past year, offering hypoallergenic rooms, free workout gear and now special menus for discerning eaters. Last month, Casa del Mar (hotelcasadelmar.com) in Santa Monica, Calif., introduced a gluten-free menu at its restaurant Catch (a striped bass offering, above). Both celiac disease sufferers, who cannot process gluten, found in cereals like wheat, and unrestricted diners have shown interest, according to staff members.

headline.main: Hotel Menus Adapt To Special Diets

docs.abstract: In Transit blog; some hotel restaurants are offering special menu items for health-conscious diners; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: 10 P.M. (A&E) BREAKOUT KINGS This new drama by Matt Olmstead and Nick Santora, the writers and producers of Fox's defunct ''Prison Break,'' is about two United States marshals (Domenick Lombardozzi, above left, and Laz Alonso) assigned to track down escaped felons. But, as the show's tagline puts it, ''It takes a con to catch a con.'' Or, in this case, three (Jimmi Simpson, Malcolm Goodwin and Serinda Swan), who receive upgraded accommodations and time shaved off their sentences in exchange for their efforts. ''Law & Order'' it's not. ''Matt and I really wanted to do a show where the heroes weren't earnest,'' Mr. Santora said, about the series's humor and verbal sparring, in an interview in The New York Times. ''Nothing is more boring than a procedural show where everyone is in lock step and acting as if it's the most important work in the world. I'd rather gouge my eyes out than watch one of them.'' 10 A.M. (Fox) FOX NEWS SUNDAY WITH CHRIS WALLACE Margie Phelps, a lawyer for the Westboro Baptist Church in Topeka, Kan., and a daughter of its founder, the Rev. Fred Phelps, discusses the Supreme Court ruling in Snyder v. Phelps that found the church not liable for a $5 million jury award to Albert Snyder, the father of a Marine who was killed in Iraq. Church members appeared at the funeral with signs like ''America Is Doomed.'' The church contends that the deaths of soldiers in Iraq and Afghanistan are God's way of punishing the United States for its tolerance of homosexuality.
